msgs.text: KYC *(under construction)* KYC stands for "know your customer." For tax purposes as well as anti-money laundering (AML) regulations and counter terrorism financing (CTF) laws, custodial/regulated exchanges are forced to obtain personal identification from its users such as name, birthday, cell number, social security number, and photo ID. For privacy reasons, it is recommended that advanced Bitcoiners start to stack non-KYC Bitcoin (also known as "secret sats"). There are multiple ways to do this. Mining Bitcoin is an easy (but not so easy) way to earn KYC-free Bitcoin. See more in Bitcoin ATMs can also be used to purchase Non-KYC Bitcoin, find one near you here: https://coinatmradar.com/ Some Bitcoin ATMs require SMS verification. In order to stay KYC-free, you'll need to use either a burner phone not connected to your ID or the website https://textverified.com/ Also, make sure that the email address associated with your account and money you send to TextVerified isn't tied to your identity. You can pay in Bitcoin. I sent Bitcoin to my account via a lightning wallet that isn't tied to my identity. As you can see, getting KYC-free Bitcoin is a pain in the ass. On top of this struggle, Bitcoin ATMs charge outrageously high fees...usually around 8.4%. Non-KYC Bitcoin should be kept separately in a different wallet than your KYC Bitcoin; don't mix the stacks. Your non-KYC wallet should not be linked to your identity in any way else it ruins the purpose of a non-KYC stack. More on KYC: https://bitcoinmagazine.com/culture/bitcoin-will-protect-your-personal-data Lots of resources/information on the process of purchasing Non-KYC Bitcoin here: https://99bitcoins.com/buy-bitcoin/anonymously-without-id/

LIGHTNING PRIVACY Transacting on the Lightning Network is very private. Lightning transactions are not broadcast on the Blockchain. The sender and receiver are the only two parties who are aware of the lighting transaction that they are making, and in most cases, the receiver doesn't even know who the sender is because the routing among lightning channels is with encrypted data.

CROSS-INPUT SIGNITURE AGGREGRATION In this future upgrade to Bitcoin, exchanges will be able to transact together which will effectively coinjoin everyone's coins, protecting our privacy and combatting surveillance. The exchanges will be incentivized to do this because the fees will be lower than normal transactions. More: https://jimmysong.substack.com/p/the-future-of-bitcoin-privacy-cross

COINJOIN Coinjoining is a process that mixes your coins so that their path to your wallet is jumbled and impossible to follow. This comes with risk, because after you CoinJoin, it is known by a third party that those coins were coinjoined. Some exchanges choose not to accept coinjoined coins on their platform, so you could be left with fewer options when you choose to sell your coins. You should weigh these risks when considering coinjoining.

history of upgrades made on other coins that were eventually implemented on Bitcoin:
- Namecoin and colored coins inspired the creation of OP_RETURN.
- SegWit was implemented on Litecoin before it came to Bitcoin.
- Ring signatures and stealth addresses, pioneered by Monero, influenced Bitcoin privacy research and concepts like scriptless scripts and Silent Payments.
- Zero-knowledge proofs (Zcash and beyond) accelerated exploration of zk-based verification and client proofs for Bitcoin.
- MimbleWimble introduced new ways to aggregate and compress transactions â€“ ideas that informed work on CoinJoin efficiency, CTV, and general scalability discussions.
- Utreexo, which is promising tech and has been discussed at Bitdevs meetups, implemented on Siacoin this year.
